source.335798e5:
miss = pd.concat([df.isnull().sum(),
                  100 * df.isnull().sum()/len(df)],
                 axis=1).rename(columns={0:'Missing Records',
                                         1:'Percentage (%)'}
                               ).sort_values(by='Percentage (%)',
                                             ascending=False)
trace = go.Bar(
        y=miss.index[::-1],
        x=miss['Percentage (%)'][::-1],
        showlegend=False,
        orientation = 'h',
        marker=dict(color='firebrick',))
data = [trace]
layout = dict(title = 'Percentage (%) missing values in train set',
              margin  = dict(l = 200))
fig = go.Figure(data=data, layout=layout)
py.iplot(fig)

source.c568b0ca:
def pietrace(df, col_name=None,title=None):
    value_st=df[col_name].loc[df['target']==0.0].value_counts() 
    value_ng=df[col_name].loc[df['target']==1.0].value_counts()
        
    # Create subplots: use 'domain' type for Pie subplot
    fig = make_subplots(rows=1, cols=2, specs=[[{'type':'domain'}, {'type':'domain'}]])
    fig.add_trace(go.Pie(labels=list(value_st.index),values=list(value_st.values), 
                         scalegroup='one',name="stay in job"),1, 1)
    fig.add_trace(go.Pie(labels=list(value_ng.index), values=list(value_ng.values),
                         scalegroup='one',name="change in job"),1, 2)

    # Use `hole` to create a donut-like pie chart
    fig.update_traces(hole=.4, hoverinfo="label+value+percent+name")

    fig.update_layout(title_text=title,
        # Add annotations in the center of the donut pies.
        annotations=[dict(text='Stay', x=0.18, y=0.5, font_size=13, showarrow=False),
                     dict(text='Change', x=0.82, y=0.5, font_size=11, showarrow=False)])
    fig.update_yaxes(automargin=True)                   
    return fig.show()

source.5daadcde:
def boxtrace(df, col_name=None,title=None):
    value_st=df[col_name].loc[df['target']==0.0]
    value_ng=df[col_name].loc[df['target']==1.0]
 
    x_data=['Stay','Change']
    y_data=[value_st,value_ng]
    colors = ['rgba(93, 164, 214, 0.5)','rgba(255, 144, 14, 0.5)']
    fig = go.Figure()

    for xd, yd, cls in zip(x_data, y_data, colors):
        fig.add_trace(go.Box(y=yd,
                             name=xd,
                             boxpoints='all',
                             fillcolor=cls,))
        fig.update_layout(title=title,
                          yaxis=dict(autorange=True,
                                     showgrid=True,
                                     zeroline=True,
                                     gridcolor='rgb(255, 255, 255)',
                                     zerolinecolor='rgb(255, 255, 255)',),
                          margin=dict(l=40,r=30,b=80,t=100,),
                          paper_bgcolor='rgb(243, 243, 243)',
                          plot_bgcolor='rgb(243, 243, 243)',
                          showlegend=False)
    fig.show()

#droping city_ and converting to int
df['citi_number']=df['city'].str.strip('city_')
df['citi_number']=df['citi_number'].astype(int)
#df['citi_number'].head()
fig = go.Figure(data=go.Scatter(
    x= df['citi_number'],
    y = df['city_development_index'],
    mode='markers',
    marker=dict(
        size=16,
        color=df['target'], #set color equal to a variable
        colorscale='Viridis', # one of plotly colorscales
        showscale=True)))

                 xaxis=dict(title="city names"),yaxis=dict(title='development index'))          
fig.show()
source.bbf15f9c:
cleannums={'experience': {">20":25,"<1":0.5}}
df=df.replace(cleannums)
df['experience']=df['experience'].astype(float)
df['experienceGroup']=pd.cut(df.experience,[0,5,12,19,25],labels=['0-5','6-12','13-19','20 & above'])
#create table group by
Job=df.groupby(['target','last_new_job'])['experienceGroup'].value_counts().unstack()
Job.columns=Job.columns.tolist()
Job.reset_index(inplace=True)
#Job.style.background_gradient('coolwarm')
fig = px.bar(Job, x='last_new_job', y=['0-5','6-12','13-19','20 & above'],
             color_discrete_map={'0-5':'limegreen','6-12':'salmon','13-19':'lightblue',
                                '20 & above':'indigo'},
             facet_col="target",
             template="simple_white")
fig.update_layout(title_text="Which age group wants to change Job frequently?",
                  yaxis = dict(title ='Count of members in each experience group'),
                  annotations=[dict(text='Stay', x=0.3, y=1.0, font_size=18, showarrow=False),
                               dict(text='Change', x=0.7, y=1.0, font_size=18, showarrow=False)])
fig.update_xaxes(title ='Last job change(in yrs)')
fig.show()

source.679621e3:
### This notebook is part one and does not cover all the analysis. New plots and analysis are available in[Part 2 of EDA](https://www.kaggle.com/ipsita001/hr-analytics-why-they-look-for-change-part2) This dataset designed to understand the factors that lead a person to leave current job, by using the current credentials,demographics,experience data we have here. **Task one:** **we need to predict the probability of a candidate to look for a new job or will work for the company.** **Task two:** **interpreting affected factors on employee decision.** **Features** 1. enrollee_id : Unique ID for candidate 2. city: City code 3. city_ development _index : Developement index of the city (scaled) 4. gender: Gender of candidate 5. relevent_experience: Relevant experience of candidate 6. enrolled_university: Type of University course enrolled if any 7. education_level: Education level of candidate 8. major_discipline :Education major discipline of candidate 9. experience: Candidate total experience in years 10. company_size: No of employees in current employer's company 11. company_type : Type of current employer 12. lastnewjob: Difference in years between previous job and current job 13. training_hours: training hours completed 14. target: 0 – Not looking for job change, 1 – Looking for a job change **

plz upvote if you find this one useful. Codes are hidden,incase you are unable to see the code button use firefox browser.

**
source.045a6e18:
**Findings on frequency of job change**
1. This is quite interesting observation. It shows how many years back they last time change their jobs. We get an idea about the frequency of their job change. 
2. Here interestingly, 1 year is the time line where most employess who are looking for a change followed by who never changed in past and then who changed 2 years back. Those who change are actually changing 1 year and 2 year gap. 
3. Employees who are staying, similarly 1 year followed by 4+ years then 2 years they last change their job.
source.737d8398: 1. Here is an interesting finding. 6 to 20+ experience group with relevant experience are leaving. They are more in number than no relevent group. But surprisingly below 5 experience with no relevant experience are leaving more than with it.
source.63e80ef7: ## Summary of our findings. **This summary is focused on gender disparity, experience of different generation and reasons they want to leave or stay** 1. We have 25% of employees leaving and 75% staying back. 2. Most of the employees belong private sector and most of them are men. 3. Many employees prefer to stay in developed cities, mostly under developed city people are leaving. 4. Gender disparity is a reality in job sectors. Our analysis too shows, women and others are neglected. They are staying back or leaving is just a choice. Their education relevance has nothing to help them. 5. Graduates will leave and we more graduates. 6. Younger generation even if they dont have relevant experience will leave. All genders,graduates or not, whatever be the mode of education or company size and type, the younger they are more likely to leave.

2. We have very few women with 20+ experience as compared to young group(below 5).
3. Even less number of people in others gender leaving the job. Men are more likely to change than women. Others are likely to stay back with more experience.
source.ecdc7523:
1. Purple denotes employees who wants to stay and yellow denotes those who want a change. 
2. Lets put an imaginary line at 6.5 development index on y axis.Most of the yellow dots are below 6.5 index and purple dots above this line. We have already seen in box plot that more employees look for a change in cities with low development index. 
3. Here we can see the yellow dots mostly have low dvelopment index. City development is an important factor who look for change.
source.93efe972: ## Deep analysis on experience Now we will analyse experience of our employees into much deeper. we have analysed experience vs target. 1. We have few employees with 1,2 years of experience but they are the one leaving more. If we look at employees looking for a change, 10% of them have 20+ years of experience. Another 10% having 3 years of experience are also leaving. So, we will devide them in 4 buckets. 1. young_group- 0 to 5 years 2. Mid_senior_group- 6 to 12 years 3. Senior_group- 13 to 19 years 4. Older_group- 20 years and above first will replace >20 to 25, and make it numeric and devide into groups.

**Findings on gender:** 
1. We have more male employees than female. Others are the least in number. 
2. For all the employees staying and working for company, 90% (10,200)male and only 8.1% (912)female.
3. For all the employees looking for a job change 88% (3000)male and only 9.6% (326)female.
4. 141 "others" will continue to work and where as 50 of them are looking for a change. 
5. If we look at the ratio then more women and "others" are looking for a change than men.

source.14aa1d3c:
**Findings on employee experience**

1. For all the employees going to work for company, 19% are of 20+ years of experience and highest number of employees belongs to this category.
2. At the same time, if we look at employees looking for a change, 10% of them have 20+ years of experience. Another 10% having 3 years of experience are also leaving. 
3. Here another interesting observation about employees. Nearly 2% (285) of total staying have <1 year experience, 237 which is 5% of total leaving. Similar observation with 2 years experience people. 
4. We have few employees with 1,2 years of experience but they are the one leaving more.

2. Other majors are very few in numbers. Most of the data scientists have STEM background are good in knowledge in general.

source.0c4bc824:
**Findings on education level**
1. Most of our employess are graduates and very few have PHD and primary school education. 
2. While 8300 graduates are going to work for company then 3200 are going to leave. More graduates are looking for a change than any other professionals.
source.118689df:
**Findings on relevant experience**
1. we have more employees with relevant experience and 75%(10000) of such employees are staying back.Good news. 2961 employees are looking for achange.  
2. All employees with no relevant experience, 3550 will stay in job and 1816 are looking for change. 
3. Here if we consider employees no relevant experience are not very useful, then more employees are staying back than those are looking for a change. All those who are looking for a change 62% are having relevant experience.
source.518bd3fa:
**Findings on company type**
1. Most of our companies data are about private sector. As many of our "company type" data is missing. cant conclude anything.
source.30d0f4be:
1. Here the finding will be baised towards no enrollment group as they have huge number than other mode of education. 
2. Employees with full time course are more likely to leave than part time.
